Boots are a type of armor that covers the feet of the player. There are five types of boots: leather boots, chain boots, iron boots, diamond boots and gold boots.
Shields are tools used for protecting the player against attacks.
Horse armor is a special type of armor that can be given to a horse to wear.

Snowballs are throwable items. In the Computer Edition, they deal no damage to other mobs, but mobs will still have knockback and give the same effect as if they were being damaged. In both versions, they can still damage armor.
Axes are tools used to ease the process of collecting wood based items.
Pickaxes are one of the most commonly used tools in the game, being required to mine all ores and many other types of blocks.
Shovels are tools used to ease the process of collecting dirt and other blocks.
Hoes are tools used to till dirt and grass blocks into farmland blocks.
The flint and steel is a tool used to light fires.
Leads, also known as leashes, are items used to leash and lead passive mobs.
Buckets are tools used to carry water, lava, or milk.
Compasses are an item used to point to the world spawn.
A map is an item used to view explored terrain.
Clocks are items that display the current in-game time by displaying the sun and the moon\'s position relative to the horizon.
Fishing rods are tools that are mainly used for obtaining fish.
A carrot on a stick is an item that can be used to control saddled pigs.
Shears are a tool used primarily to shear sheep and mine a few types of blocks.
Fire charges are items which light fires when used.

Wood planks are used in many crafting recipes. Doors, fences, fence gates, slab, and stairs – and boats in all editions except the Console Edition – must be crafted from wood planks of the same type and will match the wood type used. For other products, wood planks of different types can be mixed freely, with no effect on the result.
The crafting table (also referred to in an achievement as the workbench) is one of the most essential blocks in Minecraft.
A stick is an item used for crafting many tools and items.
Torches are non-solid blocks that emit light. Torches give off a light level of 14. Torches also melt snow layers and ice within 2 blocks (taxicab distance).
A furnace is a block used to smelt blocks and items and convert them into other blocks or items.
A chest is a block that stores items.

Ender chests are a type of chest that can store items, although the contents of an Ender Chest are bound to the player opening it, not the ender chest being opened, regardless of where it is (or what dimension it\'s in). Ender chests can be opened by pressing use. If a solid block is placed above an ender chest, it will not be able to open. Ender chests can be used like chests, except all ender chests in the world share the same inventory, including in different dimensions. The ender chest\'s inventory is also separate for each player; consequently, items stored in an ender chest cannot be seen or taken by other players.
An enchantment table is a block that allows players to spend their experience point levels to enchant tools, books and armor.
Anvils are blocks that use the item repair interface to repair and to rename items, as well as to combine enchantments.
Paintings are decorative entities that hang on walls.
Signs are non-solid blocks that can display text.
Ladders are wooden blocks used for climbing walls either vertically or horizontally. They can only be placed on the sides of other blocks.
Paper is an item crafted from sugar cane.
Books are items crafted from paper and leather.
Books and quills are items used to write written books.
Fences are wall blocks that cannot normally be jumped over.

Fences are wall blocks that cannot normally be jumped over. Wood fences are broken most quickly with an axe, but will drop when broken with any tool. Nether brick fences require a pickaxe to get it back, mining it with anything else will drop nothing.

Cobblestone walls are decorative blocks. There are 2 types: cobblestone walls and mossy cobblestone walls.\nCobblestone walls are one and a half blocks tall for player/mob collision, and one block tall for all other purposes, similar to fences. This prevents players and mobs from jumping over them, while using only one actual block space. A wall occupies the center space of blocks and automatically connects to any solid block that is placed next to it. Since their hitbox is smaller than a single block, it will allow a mob in the block to breathe even when submerged.
Cobblestone walls are more efficient at fencing off mobs than a two-block high wall of cobblestone, costing only half as many blocks, and being more space-efficient as well. The drawback, however, is that a skeleton might shoot over the wall, a creeper could explode if a player is standing near the wall and a spider could still climb over the wall.
Unlike fences, if two cobblestone walls are placed one block apart diagonally, you cannot walk between them.
A bed is a block that allows a player to sleep and to reset their spawn point to within a few blocks of the bed.
Glass is a decorative fully transparent block which can be dyed into stained glass.
Glass panes are transparent blocks which can be used as a much more efficient alternative to glass blocks.
Glass panes are much more efficient than glass, as they can make windows of 267% the area of glass blocks, because only 6 glass blocks are required to make 16 glass panes.
A door is a block that can be used as a switchable barrier. Wood doors can be opened and closed by players and villagers, and can be broken by zombies in Hard mode.
Slabs are half-versions of their respective blocks.
Stairs are blocks that allow mobs and players to change elevation without jumping.
A boat is both an item and a vehicle entity.
A trapdoor is a solid, transparent block that can be used as an openable barrier.
Wooden trapdoors can be mined with anything, but an axe is fastest. Iron trapdoors require a pickaxe to mine. Trapdoors will remain in place if their attachment block is moved, removed, or destroyed.

A pressure plate is a non-solid block that can be used to detect players, mobs, items, etc. There are two versions of the pressure plate: the stone pressure plate and the wooden pressure plate. The only difference between the two are which entities they can detect.

A weighted pressure plate is a block that can be used to measure the number of entities on it. There are two versions of the weighted pressure plate: the light weighted pressure plate (aka "gold plate") and the heavy weighted pressure plate (aka "iron plate"). The only difference between the two are the number of entities required to produce specific signal strengths.
Bowls are containers which are used to hold certain meals.
A button is a non-solid block which can provide temporary redstone power.
A tripwire hook is a block that can be used to detect entities (players, mobs, items, etc.) when part of a tripwire circuit.
A trapped chest is a block that stores items and which produces redstone power when opened. It can be visually distinguished from normal chests by a red coloration around the latch.
A fence gate is a block that shares the functions of both the door and the fence.

Bookshelves are blocks that primarily serve to enhance enchanting with an enchantment table. If an enchantment table is placed near a bookshelf, glyph particles will fly from a bookshelf towards the enchantment table. Having bookshelves in the proper position near the table will allow the table to apply higher-level enchantments.
A note block is a musical block that emits sounds when powered with redstone.
A jukebox is a block used to play music discs.
Pistons are blocks capable of pushing most blocks, depending on the direction they are facing. They come in two varieties: a regular piston, and a sticky piston, which can also pull movable blocks.
A redstone torch is a non-solid block that can be used as an invertible redstone power source.
A lever is a non-solid block which can provide switchable redstone power.
An item frame is an entity that displays the item or block that is inside it.
Armor stands are entities that are able to hold and display wearable items.
Banners are tall decorative blocks, featuring a field that is highly customizable using dyes.
A jack o\'lantern is a solid block that provides light.

(Stained using dyes).\nA shulker box is a block that can store and transport items. Unlike other storage units, such as chests, shulker boxes keep their items when broken, which can be retrieved when placed again. Shulker boxes will drop as an item if pushed by pistons, and can be placed using dispensers. When holding a shulker box with items inside, the items will be listed as properties. Items inside the shulker box are listed below the block type properties. Shulker boxes can be stored in other containers, though they cannot be stored in other shulker boxes. A shulker box can hold the same amount of items as a chest. (27 slots)
A block of iron is a decorative mineral block made from iron ingots.
A block of gold is a decorative mineral block crafted from gold ingots.
A lapis lazuli block is a decorative mineral block that is crafted from lapis lazuli. It is a medium blue color, with darker and lighter blue markings on it.
A block of diamond is a decorative mineral block.
A block of emerald is a decorative mineral block.
The block of coal is a mineral block that can also be used as a fuel.
Bone blocks are decorative blocks that can face in different directions.
Iron bars are blocks that serve a similar purpose to glass panes, but made of iron instead of glass blocks.
A cauldron can be crafted from iron ingots.
An eye of ender (or ender eye) is a craftable item used to locate and activate end portals within strongholds.
An end crystal, or by its entity ID, ender crystal, is both an item and an entity found in the End.
A beacon is a unique block that projects a light beam skyward and can provide status effects to players in the vicinity.
A flower pot is a decorative block that allows plants in it.
Firework stars are items used to determine the color, effect and shape of firework rockets.
Firework rockets are items and entities used to create decorative explosions and to boost players flying with elytra.
End rods are decorative light sources that emit white particles.
Hay bales are decorative, flammable blocks that can also be fed to horses.
Written books are an item created after a book and quill is signed. It appears as the same red book, but without the quill, and has an enchanted-looking glint.
Wood, or log (from the name ID), is a naturally occurring block found in trees, primarily used to create wood planks. It comes in six species: oak, birch, spruce, jungle, dark oak, and acacia.
Coal lumps are items mainly obtained by harvesting coal ore blocks. Their main uses are as a fuel or crafting torches.

Charcoal is an alternative to coal obtained from smelting wood. It can do everything coal can, except be traded with villagers or crafted into a block of coal. Coal and charcoal also cannot stack together.
Cobblestone is a common block, obtained from mining stone. Its texture resembles an uneven, roughly paved surface. Cobblestone is mainly used for crafting or as a common building block.

Wool is a block derived from sheep that can be dyed in any of the 16 different colors, which are white, orange, magenta, light blue, yellow, lime green, pink, gray, light gray, cyan, purple, blue, brown, green, red, and black.
Obsidian is a navy blue block with purple specks known for its high blast resistance and strength.
Diamonds are one of the rarest and most recognizable materials in Minecraft.
Iron ingots are versatile metal crafting ingredients. They are most commonly obtained by smelting iron ore.
Nether bricks are blocks used to form nether fortresses in the Nether.
Sand is a block affected by gravity. Red sand is a variation of sand, the only difference being its color.
Stone is a block found in abundance in the Overworld.
Sandstone and red sandstone are solid blocks, with sandstone commonly found in deserts and beaches, and red sandstone found in mesas.
Bricks are a decorative building block.
Brick is an item used to craft brick blocks and flower pots.
Clay is the item obtained from clay blocks used for crafting or making bricks.
Stone bricks are one of the materials that are used in strongholds and in the basements of igloos.
A block of quartz is a mineral block used only for decoration.
Nether quartz, or simply quartz, is an item mined exclusively in the Nether.
Purpur blocks and purpur pillars are decorative blocks that are naturally generated in end city dungeons in the End.
Popped chorus fruit is an item obtained by smelting chorus fruit, and used to craft purpur blocks. Unlike raw chorus fruit, the popped fruit is inedible.
Leather is a versatile crafting material. Cows, mooshrooms, horses and llamas drop up to 2 pieces of leather upon death.
Gold ingots are a metal which is used to craft the second tier of armor, and the first of tools.
Lapis lazuli is a primary color dye and an enchanting item.

Emeralds are an uncommon material, and are the currency used in villager trading. Emerald ore is mined using an iron or diamond pickaxe and will drop one emerald. If the pickaxe is enchanted with fortune, it may drop an extra emerald per level of Fortune, up to a maximum of 4 with Fortune III. If the ore is mined using a pickaxe enchanted with Silk Touch, it will drop itself instead of emeralds.
An ender pearl is an item which is used to teleport. Endermen drop 0–1 ender pearl when killed.
Blaze powder is an item made from a blaze rod obtained from a blaze.
Gunpowder is an item that is used for explosive-related actions.
Coal ore is a mineral block that drops coal when mined.
Iron ore is a mineral block found underground. It is the most common mineral that can be used to make tools and armor.
Lapis lazuli ore is the ore block from which lapis lazuli is obtained.
Diamond ore is a mineral block that is one of the most valuable and elusive blocks in the game.
Gold ore is one of the rarest types of mineral blocks found underground.
Emerald ore is the rarest mineral block in the game, which drops emerald when mined.
Nether quartz ore is the only ore available in the Nether.
An iron nugget is an item obtained by smelting iron tools, weapons, or armor.
A nether brick is an item made by smelting netherrack in a furnace.
Netherrack is a rock-like block found in the Nether.
A sponge is a block that can be used to remove water around itself when placed, turning into a wet sponge in the process.
Carpets are thin blocks which are mainly used for decoration.
Nether wart blocks are decorative blocks crafted using nether wart.
Andesite is a type of igneous rock. Andesite can be mined using any pickaxe. If mined without a pickaxe, it will drop nothing.
Diorite is a type of igneous rock. Diorite can be mined using any pickaxe. If mined without a pickaxe, it will drop nothing.
Granite is a type of igneous rock. Granite can be mined using any pickaxe. If mined without a pickaxe, it will drop nothing.
A totem of undying is an item which can save a player from death.
A snow block is a full-sized block of snow.
Blaze rods are items which are dropped by blazes.
Prismarine is a stone-like material that only appears underwater in ocean monuments.
Prismarine bricks are a decorative form of prismarine with a sawtooth-edged brick pattern.
Dark prismarine is a decorative form of prismarine; it is dark, with a tight grid pattern.
Sea lanterns are underwater light sources that appear in ocean monuments.
Prismarine crystals are items obtained by defeating guardians and elder guardians.
Prismarine shards are items obtained by defeating guardians or elder guardians.
The nether star is an item drop from the wither that is used solely to craft beacons.
A command block is a block that can execute commands. Because it cannot be obtained in survival mode without cheats, it is primarily used on multiplayer servers and in custom maps.
The dropper is a block that can be used to eject items, or push items into another container.
Glowstone is a light-emitting block that appears in the Nether.
A redstone lamp is a block which produces light when activated with a redstone trigger.
A redstone repeater is a block used in redstone circuits to "repeat" redstone signals back to full strength, delay signals, prevent signals moving backwards, or to "lock" signals in one state.
A redstone comparator is a block used in redstone circuits to maintain, compare, or subtract signal strength, or to measure certain block states (primarily the fullness of containers).
A daylight sensor is a block that outputs a redstone signal based on sunlight (or lack thereof).
A block of redstone acts as a piston-movable redstone power source which cannot be turned off.
Redstone is a flat transparent block which can transmit redstone power.
An observer is a block that emits a redstone signal when an adjacent block is updated.
A hopper is a block that can be used to catch item entities, or to transfer items into and out of containers.
A dispenser is a solid block used as a redstone component to dispense items.
Feathers are items dropped by chickens.
A somewhat unsettling ambient track consisting mostly of cave noises, metallic clinks, splashes, wind blowing, and muffled bow firings.
An upbeat, synthetic melody. In the .minecraft directory, the music disc plays another tune by C418, titled Dog.
A calm piece of serene music.
The record starts off with an excerpt from Chopin\'s Funeral March played on synth organ but goes into an electronic, upbeat, exploration and adventure tune with a dark undertone.

A slightly disturbing disk, the recording seems to be of a person running across (or maybe breaking) different block types and later on, stopping to use equipment of some kind, cough, and then continue running with a hastened pace. The block sounds similar to that of dirt and stone. The person struggling, and haunting background noises are heard throughout the recording. Strange noises of barking or wind blowing are heard near the end before abruptly stopping. One can hear static noise akin to what would be expected at the end of a vinyl album after this point before ending.
An upbeat and relaxing song, with a "blocky" feel to it. This disc is the latest to be added to Minecraft, although it has existed in the game data for quite some time (as where are we now).

string-array.name: commands
string-array.item:
/stats block <x> <y> <z> clear <stat>
 /stats block <x> <y> <z> set <stat> <selector> <objective>
 /stats entity <selector2> clear <stat>
 /stats entity <selector2> set <stat> <selector> <objective>

/worldborder add <distance> [time]
 /worldborder center <x> <z>
/worldborder damage amount <damagePerBlock>
/worldborder damage buffer <distance> 
/worldborder get
/worldborder set <distance> [time]
/worldborder warning distance <distance>
/worldborder warning time <time>

/whitelist add <player>
 /whitelist list
 /whitelist off
 /whitelist on
 /whitelist reload
 /whitelist remove <player>

resources.string: Sets a trigger to be activated.
Connects to an automation server (developer use only).
Modifies the data tag of a block.
Copies blocks from one place to another.
Gives or removes an achievement from a player.
Modifies the data tag of an entity.
Modifies the data tag of an entity.
Fills a region with a specific block.
Sets or queries a game rule value.
Gives an item to a player.
Displays coordinates for the closest instance of a given structure.
Replaces items in the inventories of blocks (chest, furnaces, etc.) or entities (players or mobs) with the given item(s).
Sends a message in the chat to other players.
Manages objectives, players, teams, and tags.
Changes a block to another block.
Summons an entity (mobs, projectiles, items, vehicles, etc.).
Sends a JSON message to players.
Counts entities (players, mobs, items, etc.) matching specified conditions.
Tests whether a certain block is in a specific location.
Tests whether the blocks in two regions match.
Changes or queries the world\'s game time.
These commands control the world border.
Adds an IP address to the blacklist.
Starts or stops a debugging session.

If not display recipes, there are inscriptions "empty", there are no images, then RECREATE the RECIPE DATABASE! To do this, click on the 3 dots in the upper right corner and click "Restore recipe database". After these actions, everything should work fine.
If you enjoy using this app, would you mind taking a moment to rate it? It won\'t take more than a minute. Thank for you support!

This manta-ray–like monster is a flying creature that spawns at high altitudes. It is attracted to insomnia, and will find players who haven\'t slept for many days. It will swoop down in groups and bite your flesh. Phantoms are common, undead flying hostile mobs that attack players who haven\'t slept in over three in-game days. Phantoms spawn in the Overworld at night, or at any time during a thunderstorm; high above players that have not slept for at least 3 days. Phantoms will spawn more often the longer a player has gone without sleep. When idle, phantoms will fly around in a circle at a constant y-elevation, leaving a trail of gray smoke while doing so. They have a quite large search radius, and will occasionally either swoop down or up quickly to attack their victim. If stopped or hurt during this action, the phantom will retreat back to its original elevation. When idle over water, the phantom will sometimes swoop into the water and will die as it is not pushed back up. Phantoms are able to move through water at the same speed as they do normally. When under the Invisibility effect, the phantom\'s body will disappear, but its eyes and smoke particles will still be visible. Like zombies and skeletons, phantoms will burn in sunlight.

Drowned are common hostile undead mobs that spawn in all oceans and rivers, swamps, or when a zombie drowns. They are also currently the only source of tridents. Drowned will naturally spawn at light level of 7 or less in ocean biomes (all variants), and in river and swamp biomes. They spawn at the bottom of the body of water they are in, and walk on the bottom instead of swimming like other mobs. Drowned have a chance to spawn with either a trident or a fishing rod, and occasionally with a nautilus shell. They also have a small chance of spawning while riding a chicken, even after drowning as a zombie, creating a drowned chicken jockey. This is the only zombie counterpart within the game that can not spawn naturally with any armor. If a zombie is underwater and not in a boat continuously for 30 seconds, it begins the process of converting to a drowned. Once this happens, it will start shaking, a similar effect to when a zombie villager is being cured. At this point the process cannot be stopped, and 15 seconds later the zombie will turn into a drowned. A zombie that is being drowned. (Click to see the animation) If a zombie is holding or wearing an item when it becomes a drowned, it will drop the item it is holding or wearing, 100% of the time if it had picked the item up, or the normal 8.5% +1% per looting level if it spawned with the item naturally. Zombie villagers do not transform, and husks will not transform instantly, instead transforming into a regular zombie as a midway point. Drowned have a melee attack, and if they spawn with a trident, they will use it as a ranged weapon including underwater. Each trident is thrown every 1.5 second and will not be enchanted. In the Bedrock Edition drowned with tridents will use a melee attack if the target is 3 blocks away or less. They will intentionally stomp on turtle eggs, attack baby turtles and pufferfish, and like zombies will chase and attack villagers and iron golems. If on land, drowned will seek out nearby water. They will sometimes step onto land, but will quickly return to the water. If a drowned is in anyway removed by force from the water, and all nearby water sources has been blocked from it, it becomes passive in daytime, however will go to the nearest water source when provided and once again becomes hostile as soon as it contacts water. During the day, drowned only swim to attack players that are swimming in the water with them; otherwise, they stay on the floor of the water body they are in, ignoring players that are on land or in a boat. They remain passive to players not in contact with water and will not attack them during the day only. This is because drowned will stay in water to prevent burning in sunlight. However, at night, drowned swim to the surface and will chase players as well as baby turtles, even outside the water, like regular zombies, since they cannot burn at that time. The speed of their swim is equal to that of the player. If a drowned kills a villager with a thrown trident, the villager has a chance of turning into a zombie villager.

Turtles[Java Edition only] or sea turtles[Bedrock Edition only] are common passive mobs that move both on land and in water. Turtles spawn in the Overworld on warm beaches, occasionally in small groups of up to 5 individuals. Baby turtles can occasionally spawn naturally.[Bedrock Edition only] Turtles can both move around on land and swim in water. They move slowly on land, but they can swim at a fast speed in water. Like other passive mobs, they will move around aimlessly and will flee when attacked. When on land, they will generally attempt to move to the nearest water source. When on top of eggs, they levitate. Turtles will follow a player holding seagrass. Turtles cannot be attached to leads.

Social creatures of habit, dolphins can be found swimming together through the ocean in large groups. As they spot the player, they will try to interact with them, showing them just how highly intelligent and curious they are. Above all else – they are extremely playful! Dolphins are neutral mobs that live in the ocean. Dolphins are found in large groups in all ocean biomes, except frozen oceans. Dolphins will normally swim in groups, occasionally leaping out of the water to get air, they\'re also able to jump from one body of water to another. They will also try to chase after players in boats. They are also able to ride in boats themselves and can thus be transported. Players who swim near dolphins will receive Dolphin\'s Grace for 5 seconds.[Java Edition only] On the Bedrock Edition, the player simply gets a speed boost without a status effect. Dolphins are lured by dropped items, knocking them around and chasing them.[Java Edition only] If the player or other mob hits a dolphin, the entire group will become hostile towards the attacker (like wolves and zombie pigmen). Feeding dolphins raw cod will improve their "trust" with you, depending on the amount of fish fed, causing them to interact with the player more. When dolphins are fed raw cod, they will swim to the nearest shipwreck or underwater ruins. Because they are locating the chest in the structures rather than the structures themselves, breaking the chests will cause the dolphin to locate a new structure with intact chests.[verify] Dolphins also avoid guardians and elder guardians.
If a dolphin is not in water, it will start taking suffocation damage after a while (about two minutes), and eventually die, similar to squids. This also applies if a dolphin rides in a boat[Java Edition only] . Dolphins cannot ride boats on the Bedrock version, similarly to squid, turtles, and all types of fish. When on land they will actively seek out a body of water. They will also start suffocating immediately after entering the nether. They can\'t survive without getting air every once in a while either, so if they stay submerged for about 4 minutes, they will begin drowning. The water breathing effect does not prevent them from drowning. Because the dolphin is an aquatic mob, they are affected by the impaling enchantment.

Cod is a friendly mob that lives in certain oceans in packs. The maximum amount of cod in the pack is 9. The player has the opportunity to get it with a bucket of water, buying a bucket of fish. In the future, with the help of this subject, you can place water and fish on the surface.

Salmon is a friendly mob that lives in certain oceans and various rivers in packs. Like cod, salmon come in different sizes. The maximum number of salmon in the pack is 6. The player has the opportunity to get it with a bucket of water, buying a bucket of fish. In the future, with the help of this subject, you can place water and fish on the surface.
A tropical fish is a friendly mob that lives in certain oceans in packs.
Pufferfish is a mob that lives in certain oceans. A delightful puffer that will fill you with a delicious poison, because you were too close :(

Sea pickles are light-emitting colonies of small stationary animals found underwater. A sea pickle colony will break instantly[Java Edition only] and drop itself as an item if broken using anything, or if the block below it breaks, dropping as many pickles as there are on the block. In Bedrock Edition, a sea pickle colony requires a few seconds to break, unlike in Java Edition, but otherwise they still have the same properties listed above. From Sea Pickle you can make a lime dye.
A conduit is a block that gives nearby players the Conduit Power status effect and attacks hostile mobs when powered by placing a certain configuration of blocks.
Nautilus shell is an item that is used for crafting conduits. Nautilus shells can be obtained as treasure from fishing and can sometimes be held by drowned.

The "Heart of the Sea" can be found using a treasure map, found in chests within shipwrecks usually found near icebergs. These shipwrecks are spruce-based, normally half of a damaged ship, and will usually be found in the water. Sometimes they are beached on land. The map will lead you to a chest which may be in the water. It will contain valuable loot, and will have a "Heart of the Sea" in the chest.

Kelp is a non-solid plant block that generates in all oceans. It has an item form that can be smelted to dried kelp. Kelp can be mined with any tool or without a tool. Breaking part of a kelp stalk will destroy the entire stalk. Each block has an undetermined chance to drop a kelp item.
Dried kelp is a food item that can be quickly eaten by the player.

Dried kelp blocks are blocks that are primarily used as a fuel in furnaces. Dried kelp blocks can be used as fuel in a furnace. It lasts 200 seconds, meaning that it is able to smelt 20 items. This is 2.5 times as long as the burning time for coal or charcoal.
Phantom membrane is a brewing item obtained from phantoms. Phantoms will drop 0–1 phantom membranes when killed by a player. Elytra can be repaired with phantom membranes in an anvil.

Tridents are a type of weapon that can be used in melee or ranged combat. Tridents are not craftable; it can only be obtained from drowned as a drop. Drowned that spawn with a trident as their natural weapon have a 8.5% chance of dropping the trident which has a random durability. Each level of Looting will increase the chance by 1 percentage point (11.5% with Looting III). Drowned can also drop a trident as one of its normal drops. The trident has a 3.7% chance, 4% chance with Looting I, 4.3% chance with Looting II and 4.7% chance with Looting III of dropping itself. [Bedrock Edition only] Only naturally-spawned drowned will spawn with a trident. Converted zombies will not.[Java Edition only] Tridents that were thrown onto the ground can be picked up, similarly to a fired arrow. Tridents that are enchanted with Loyalty will return to the thrower within seconds, the time taken will become shorter with each level of Loyalty enchanted onto the trident. Like skeleton and stray arrows, tridents fired by drowned cannot be picked up.
Scutes are items that baby turtles drop when they grow into adults. Baby turtles drop a single scute when they grow up into adults.
Throw a trident at something. Note: Throwing away your only weapon is not a good idea.
Strike a Villager with lightning. Hit a villager with lightning created by a trident with the channeling enchantment.
Turtle shells, referred to as turtle helmets in the game’s code, are items that are used for brewing or as a helmet to give the player the Water Breathing status effect.
